items.synopsis: It’s the phenomenon behind some of Australia’s hottest, driest years, and climate change could be making it more extreme. Here’s why that doesn’t guarantee catastrophe this year — or in the future.

title.children: An El Niño could be declared as early as next week: This is what it looks like when it forms

items.synopsis: It was a sunny start to the week but from today a polar air mass will sweep over south-east Australia, causing temperatures to plummet by as much as 15 degrees Celsius in 24 hours.

title.children: Hail, snow and gales to replace spring heat in a battle of the seasons

image.altText: A woman in a yellow jacket, a woman in a navy jacket sit on a green bench seat while a man stands and shouts

title.children: Just 11 seconds of answers preceded the third question on Qatar saga — and then all hell broke lose

image.altText: A whiteboard divided into columns with available rooms written on it in blue ink.

items.synopsis: This homelessness entry point was housing thousands of people last year, but as pandemic funding wanes, staff face an uphill battle to keep roofs over heads, while demand surges.

title.children: On an office whiteboard, Kasey and her team are trying to house Australia's homeless

image.altText: Close up of Alan Joyce

items.synopsis: Alan Joyce reportedly jets off with a substantial amount of cash and Qantas shares in his portfolio — but valid questions are being asked about whether he is entitled to all of it.

title.children: Alan Joyce leaves Qantas with millions in the bank, but his final scandal as CEO has slashed his last payout

image.altText: Natalie Sinclair sitting at a table, reaching towards bottles of Hysone and Hydrocortisone.

items.synopsis: The drug Natalie Sinclair takes to keep her alive is among hundreds of medications that have been in short supply in Australia, but advocates fear stockholding laws for suppliers are having little impact on the ground.

title.children: 'Pretty terrifying': Advocates say medicine shortages still an issue, despite stockholding rules

image.altText: A smiling man wearing a suit embraces a woman wearing a football uniform

items.synopsis: National Court prosecutors confirm Jenni Hermoso has filed a formal complaint about suspended Spanish soccer boss Luis Rubiales's decision to kiss her after last month's World Cup final in Sydney.

title.children: Spanish soccer star Hermoso files legal complaint over World Cup kiss

image.altText: A film photograph of a young woman wearing a RAAF uniform and smiling.

items.synopsis: After almost 40 years, a man has been charged with murder over the disappearance of 21-year-old Debra Campbell, who went missing from her home in Melbourne's south-east in 1984.

title.children: Police charge man with murder over decades-old Melbourne cold case

image.altText: A cyclist is silhouetted by the bright golden sunset.

items.synopsis: Earth has sweltered through its hottest northern-hemisphere summer ever measured, with a record-warm August capping a season of brutal and deadly temperatures, according to the World Meteorological Organization.

title.children: This August was the hottest ever recorded, UN's weather agency says

image.altText: Relaxed anonymous male teenager texting on mobile phone. His face is obscured by his hands and mobile in front of him.

items.synopsis: Recently emojis have landed some people in legal trouble in courts around the world. So what constitutes crossing the line?

title.children: Texted emojis landed these people in legal trouble. Here's how to avoid it happening to you

image.altText: People stand on Primrose Hill, one man is shirtless, a woman has her hands on her head because of the heat.

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Summer 2023 hottest on record, Rolling Stones release new album. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: YEAH. THE. GIRLS. Matildas stars Sam Kerr and Hayley Raso have been nominated for 2022-23 Women's Ballon d'or, which is awarded to the best female footballer in 2023. It's the first time two Australians have reached the shortlist for football's most prestigious individual award. Matildas captain and Chelsea star Kerr has been nominated every year since the Women's Ballon d'or was introduced in 2018, while it's Raso's first nomination. Spain and Barcelona midfielder Aitana Bonmati is the favourite, having recently claimed the UEFA Player of the Year award ahead of Kerr.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Matildas stars Sam Kerr and Hayley Raso nominated for Women's Ballon d'or

props.alt: Hayley jumps on Sam's back as they celebrate.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Rolling Stones are returning with their first original album in 18 years. The band launched their 24th studio album Hackney Diamonds at a theatre in east London before unveiling the music video to the single Angry, starring actress Sydney Sweeney. This will be the Stones' first album without long-time drummer Charlie Watts who died in 2021. The band also hinted fans can expect collaborations with Stevie Wonder and Lady Gaga – when the full album's released on October 20.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rolling Stones announce release date for new album, unveil lead single

props.alt: The three remaining band members smile on stage.

children.content: Ronnie Wood, Mick Jagger, and Keith Richards.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The summer of 2023 was the hottest on record, according to data from the European Union Climate Change Service released on Wednesday. The three-month period from June through August surpassed previous records by a large margin, with an average temperature of 16.8 degrees Celsius (62.2F) — 0.66C above average. Last month was the also the hottest August on record globally, the third straight month in a row to set such a record following the hottest ever June and July, the EU said on Wednesday. "Global temperature records continue to tumble in 2023," Copernicus deputy head Samantha Burgess said. "The scientific evidence is overwhelming, we will continue to see more climate records and more intense and frequent extreme weather events impacting society and ecosystems, until we stop emitting greenhouse gases," Burgess said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Summer 2023 was hottest on record, scientists say

children.content: The summer of 2023 was the hottest on record, according to data from the European Union Climate Change Service released on Wednesday.
The three-month period from June through August surpassed previous records by a large margin, with an average temperature of 16.8 degrees Celsius (62.2F) — 0.66C above average.
Last month was the also the hottest August on record globally, the third straight month in a row to set such a record following the hottest ever June and July, the EU said on Wednesday.
"Global temperature records continue to tumble in 2023," Copernicus deputy head Samantha Burgess said.

"The scientific evidence is overwhelming, we will continue to see more climate records and more intense and frequent extreme weather events impacting society and ecosystems, until we stop emitting greenhouse gases," Burgess said.

image.altText: A black and white photo of a woman outdoors.

items.synopsis: For three months, this Swiss adventurer walked alone for 1,500 kilometres through parts of the Nullarbor, Great Victoria Desert and Gibson Desert. She says Australia is now "in her blood".

title.children: While trekking in remote Australia, Sarah didn't speak for six weeks. She says it is 'magical'

image.altText: An historic paddle wheeler emerges from the brown water of the Thomson River, with salvage crews on pontoons and machinery.

items.synopsis: Harnesses and floaties have been used in a major operation to resurface the 99-year-old paddle wheeler.

title.children: Pride of the Murray resurfaces after six months at the bottom of an outback river

image.altText: A dam and rolling green hills.

items.synopsis: Researchers identify thousands of locations for potential micro-pumped-hydro energy storage across rural Australia, using pre-existing farm dams and rivers.

image.altText: A smiling, dark-haired man leans on a trailer full of oranges in a citrus orchard.

image.altText: Four Corners obtained footage showing the tear gassing of boys being held in isolation at the Don Dale Youth Detention Centre in Darwin, in August 201

image.altText: A woman with blue shirt and name tag sits looking up at and holding the knee of a woman who sits on a raised bed.

items.synopsis: Australia has one of the world's best healthcare systems. But senior physician Fiona Reilly argues it doesn't always work as well as it should for patients.
